secondary_findings.notes: May contribute to seizure severity or represent genetic background variation

rank_2.notes: Would be considered if SCN1A testing was negative

rank_3.notes: GABRA1 variant present but likely not primary cause given inheritance pattern

SCN1A_c.4933C>T.notes: Truncating variant in haploinsufficiency gene with de novo status

SCN9A_c.2215G>A.notes: Population frequency and computational evidence argue against pathogenicity

GABRA1_c.641G>A.notes: Rare variant but inherited from unaffected father

expected_recommendations.recommendation: Avoid sodium channel blocker antiepileptic drugs (carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin)
Continue current Dravet-appropriate regimen (valproate, clobazam, stiripentol)
Consider adding fenfluramine if seizures remain uncontrolled
SUDEP risk counseling and seizure monitoring
Counsel family on de novo inheritance and low recurrence risk
Refer to Dravet Syndrome Foundation for resources

rubric.excellent: Dravet syndrome ranked first with high confidence, SCN1A identified as causative
rubric.good: Dravet syndrome in top 2, genetic epileptic encephalopathy considered
rubric.poor: Missed SCN1A or misclassified as benign condition

rubric.excellent: All three variants correctly classified per ACMG guidelines
rubric.good: SCN1A correctly classified as pathogenic, others reasonable
rubric.acceptable: Primary variant identified but classification criteria incomplete
rubric.poor: SCN1A misclassified or causative variant missed

rubric.excellent: All key recommendations present, drug avoidance emphasized
rubric.good: Sodium channel blocker avoidance mentioned, appropriate medications listed

rubric.excellent: All sections complete with supporting evidence cited
rubric.acceptable: Core diagnosis present but limited detail

metadata.inspired_by: Composite of published Dravet syndrome cases
references: Dravet C. (2011). Dravet syndrome history. Dev Med Child Neurol. 53 Suppl 2:1-6.
Wirrell EC, et al. (2022). International consensus on diagnosis and management of Dravet syndrome. Epilepsia. 63(7):1761-1777.
Claes L, et al. (2001). De novo mutations in the sodium-channel gene SCN1A cause severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy. Am J Hum Genet. 68(6):1327-32.
